paragraphs.context: The mechanisms used to escape from the adaptive immune system are more complicated. The simplest approach is to quickly change the non-essential epitopes (amino acids and/or sugars) on the surface of the pathogen, while the essential epitopes remain hidden. This is called antigenic variation. One example is HIV, which quickly mutates, so that proteins in your viral layer, which are essential to enter your target cell, are constantly changing. These frequent changes in antigens can explain the failure of vaccines targeted at this virus. The parasite Trypanosoma brucei uses a similar strategy and constantly changes one type of surface protein to another, leaving it one step ahead of the antibody response. Antigen mask with host molecules is another common strategy to prevent detection by the immune system. paragraphs.context: Another important role of the immune system is to identify and remove tumors. This is called immune control. For the immune system, these antigens appear to be foreign, and their presence causes immune cells to attack transformed tumour cells. Tumour-expressed antigens have several sources, some of which are derived from oncogenic viruses such as the human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer, while others are the body’s own proteins that occur at low concentrations in normal cells but reach high tumour cell levels. One example is an enzyme called thyrosinase which, expressed at high levels, converts certain skin cells (e.g. melanocytes) into melanomas. The term "imperialism" is often confused with "colonialism," but many scholars have argued that each has its own definition. Imperialism and colonialism were used to describe its superiority, its rule and its influence on a person or group of people. Robert Young writes that although imperialism operates from the center, it is a government policy and is developed for ideological and financial reasons, colonialism is simply the development of settlements or trade projects. Colonialism in modern use also implies a certain geographical separation between the colony and the imperial power. In particular, Edward Said distinguishes the difference between imperialism and colonialism by saying: "Imperialism contained "the practice, theory and attitude of a dominant metropolitan center that rules a far-away territory," while colonialism refers to the "implantation of settlements on a far-away territory." Related lands such as Russian or Ottoman are generally excluded from the discussion of colonialism.:116 Thus it can be said that imperialism contains a form of colonialism, but colonialism itself does not automatically imply imperialism, because it does not have a political focus.[more explanation required]

paragraphs.context: Orientalism, theorized by Edward Said, refers to how the West developed a imaginative geography in the East. This imaginative geography is based on a revitalizing discourse that neither represents the diversity nor the social reality of the East. Rather, this discourse uses the idea of location-based identities to create the difference and distance between "we" West and "they" East, or "here" West and "there" East. This difference became particularly evident in text and visual works of the early European studies of the Orient, which made the East as irrational and backward in opposition to the rational and progressive West. The definition of the East as a negative vision of itself, as its inferiors, not only increased the self-esteem of the West, but was also an opportunity to arrange the East and make it known to the West so that it could be controlled and controlled. The Orientalism discourse therefore served as an ideological justification for early Western imperialism, as it formed a collection of knowledge and ideas that rationalized social, cultural, political and economic control over other areas.
